Hi Ron,
  Sorry no I won't be there. I live in the north of the UK so it is=
 a long trip. I am sure it will be a good event. 
  Regarding your question=
 about Naokatsu and Kajihei, I have two swords which are relevant. The firs=
t is a wakazashi which appears to be a copy of an O-suriage bizen blade whi=
ch has NBTHK green papers to Naokatsu. The second, and the one I am current=
ly investigating, appears to be an O-suriage tachi with a partial sayagaki =
to Bizen Osafune Kagemitsu. However to me and others who have seen it it ap=
pears more likely to be a shin-shinto copy. The quality of the work, partic=
ularly the hada and the Utsuri suggests Naokatsu but in trying to prove it =
the name of Kajihei cropped up. It appears he was a very accomplished smith=
 initially making copies of shinto pieces of both Kotetsu and Inoue Shinkai=
 and more latterly by Osafune school smiths. The grey area appears to be in=
 his intent. Where Naotane, Naokatsu etc made copies Kajihei appears to hav=
e made counterfeits which were intended to deceive. There are apparently ma=
ny Kotestsu blades by this smith and at least one book has been
 published =
in the past of Oshigatas of his work.
  If the sword under study is by him =
then I have no doubt that he was an incredible smith. I find it very sad th=
at such talent should be used to deceive either through circumstance or mal=
ice.

Ron Hartmann <swords@...> wrote:
          Paul - 

No info=
 for you but I did want to mention that I'm doing an exhibit on Naokatsu (a=
nd other shinshinto smiths loaned by others) at the upcoming Minneapolis sh=
ow and shinsa on the 15th. I'm curious if you have a sword by this fellow K=
ajihei and if so, are you attending this show? It promises to be a very int=
eresting "cultural" weekend taking in lots of other interests than swords. =
Should be good!

Ron
STL
----- Original Message ----- 
From: paul bowman 
T=
o: study group 
Sent: Sunday, June 03, 2007 10:30 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy=
] Kajihei

Dear All, 
Im looking for information on Kajihei, the son/studen=
t of Jiritaro Naokatsu. 
He seems to have a mixed reputation in that he was=
 a highly skilled smith but specilaised in making counterfeit blades of top=
 Koto and Shinto smiths. 
Trying to work out whether he was a victim of the=
 times trying to survive the downturn in demand for swords or just a dishon=
est but highly skilled crook. 
All information/ leads gratefully received. =

thanks 
PaulB
